comments.commentText: A fulfilling job should energize us, not drain us. Reflecting on what truly motivates us can lead to greater satisfaction and success.

posts.name:
Richard King
Richard King
posts.content:
Maybe it’s the LI algorithm…but I’m seeing a (bizarre) flex lately:

“I’ve applied to 1,000 jobs and can’t even secure an interview!”

“Yeah…well…I’ve applied to 1,500!”

“Hold my beer…I’ve applied to 2,000!!”

“Yawn…I’ve applied to 5,000….and no one will interview me!! What is happening out there?!”

I’ll tell you what is happening: you have NO IDEA what you’re doing! You’re lost in the forest walking around in circles! Just because you thought it was “easy” to find a job in 2017…you *think* you know how to do it now. YOU DO NOT!!

The two reasons *most likely* responsible for the above:

1) Your resume sucks!
2) You’re unable to assess your skills and you’re applying to jobs you’re no where near qualified for.

One of the most painful things I hear when I speak to people about their resume: “Ugh….I applied to all those jobs with my sh*tty resume…sigh…do you think I should go back and re-apply?” Answer: I don’t know. Sure, maybe if the role is still posted.

Please, stop applying to roles (and wasting your shot) until you have your resume audited by a real Recruiter! Not your mom who once worked in HR…not your hiring manager buddy…not some random person on LI who now calls themselves a career coach ()

Your resume has ONE goal: to secure a call!

comments.commentText: Do you think people are overstating their “applied but no interview” numbers? Maybe they think it will garner some sympathy or something? I mean, a broken clock is right twice a day. Surely there’s no way you can have applied to THAT many jobs and literally had zero interviews. I just don’t buy it. And I was in the market for a while, so it’s not like I’m speaking from a high horse of employment.
Aaron Glidewell, MBA I don’t know. I saw a post yesterday: “I’ve been looking for 6 months and apply to 50-70 roles a week…” That’s well over 1,000 applications. No calls?! Something is amiss.

Richard King exactly. Like not even one call? Or not one call that you wanted? 

There’s a difference between no calls at all and no calls for roles I care about.
Another thing that these type of spray and pray applications are doing is causing good candidates to get lost in the shuffle.
Dave Sneddon Yeah. I read an article the other day about the spike in applications due to LinkedIn's "easy apply".

posts.name:
Mayur Satyavrat
Mayur Satyavrat
posts.content:
Finding Magic in the Darkness: 

A Reminder of Growth and Potential

We all have moments of doubt, times when we feel stuck, lost, or like we're falling behind or may be apart. It's easy to get caught up in the negativity, wishing we had done things differently. But what if we could shift our camera & perspective

Within our struggles lies a hidden magic. Our uncertainty, our lostness, and even our discomfort are opportunities for growth and transformation. They are the seeds of change, pushing us to evolve into the best versions of ourselves.

Think about a time when you faced a challenging situation or pushed into unexpected crisis (where u didn't have any role to play). Maybe you felt overwhelmed, unsure of the next step. In retrospect, you likely realize that experience taught you valuable lessons, strengthened your resilience, and led you to a better place.

It's about recognizing that every step, every stumble, every moment of doubt is part of a larger journey. It's about trusting that the universe has a plan, and that even in the darkest of times, there is always a glimmer of hope, a chance to learn and grow.

So, the next time you find yourself feeling lost or discouraged, remember & hold onto the belief that within your struggles lies the potential for something extraordinary. It's just the bend nd not the end...One day, you will look back on this time and see the magic that unfolded, the person you became because of it.

posts.name:
Josh Gardner
Josh Gardner
posts.content:
Life doesn’t follow a straight line...

Neither does your career.

In fact, I had SEVERAL businesses fail before I finally found success (and built a life I love.)

And every single difficult experience taught me lessons that are still serving me well today.

Aswisely points out, you have permission to:

⏳ Start at your own pace.
 Make mistakes along the way.
 Pivot and change directions…

...and still build a fulfilling, successful career. 

Here are some ways to shape a career that unlocks your full potential:

Define the values that guide you.
Set ambitious, clear goals.
Commit to lifelong learning.
Pursue challenges that stretch you.
Develop complementary skills.
Network with intention.
Embrace failure, learn, adapt, and keep going.

Ask yourself these questions to help uncover your path:
 What energizes you?
 How do you want to make an impact?
 What are your strengths and passions?
 Who do you admire, and why?
 If fear weren’t a factor, what would you pursue?

Have you made a big career change? Share your experience in the comments!

posts.name:
Dale Dupree
Dale Dupree
posts.content:
This simply isn’t true.

The other two emails were in my spam.

I have no recollection of anyone reaching out to me on social.

And what’s even funnier is you’ll never guess whether I just happened to see this fourth touch…

Checking my spam because someone texted me saying “I emailed it last night, might have hit your spam folder.”

So how can there be any type of standard around the number of outreach before ‘the ball is in my court’ and you just stop pursuing me?

I will prospect into an account for years

Never sending an email like this

Instead, continuing the conversation forward

Giving a renewed and better experience as often as I possibly can…

This is just a sequence with myself and thousands of others in it

Where the sender has their fingers crossed that it’ll make its way into enough inboxes that they get some leads ‍️

The bar is low, Rebels.

Pounce on that opportunity.

I think the majority of you would agree that this seller just needs somein their life.

posts.name:
Paul Storm
Paul Storm
posts.content:
“Our employees are not children” – Spotify

(Here’s the reality check you need)

You either trust your people or you don’t.
It’s that simple.

Spotify gets it:
Remote work isn’t a luxury.
It’s a trust-building tool that empowers teams to excel.

If you think remote work leads to laziness, think again.
True engagement thrives when you replace micromanagement with freedom.

Yes, office perks are nice.
But the freedom of remote work?
That’s what truly drives engagement and results.

Building a high-performing remote team doesn’t happen overnight.
It takes commitment. Every single day.

So, what makes a remote team thrive?

1️⃣ Clear Goals and Outcomes
→ Everyone knows the mission, no matter the time zone.

2️⃣ Purposeful Communication
→ Quality over quantity: check-ins that matter, not endless messages.

3️⃣ Flexibility That Works for Everyone
→ People work best when they’re in control of their schedules, not locked into 9-to-5.

4️⃣ Trust Over Surveillance
→ Measure success by results, not screen time. Adults don’t need babysitting.

5️⃣ Asynchronous Collaboration
→ Work flows around life, not the other way around.

Why does this matter?

When employees feel trusted → They go above and beyond.
When communication is intentional → Teams stay aligned.
When flexibility is prioritized → Productivity thrives.

Leaders, pay attention:

 Remote work isn’t just an option anymore.
 It’s the cornerstone of modern success.

Do you agree?
Let’s hear your take below! 

️ Repost this to help others in your network.
And followfor more!

comments.commentText: The truth is I will over-deliver when not I’m not stuck underneath my boss’s thumb ‍️

posts.name:
Anthony Escamilla
Anthony Escamilla
posts.content:
Recruiting tools can make or break your hiring process.

Most of the time, tech stacks are either over-stuffed or missing key pieces.

Here’s what NOT to do:

 Overload your stack with tools that don’t integrate
 Rely on clunky and outdated ATS systems
 Skip CRM tools that help with candidate nurturing
 Ignore metrics and analytics tracking
 Forget about the candidate experience

Focus on what works:

 Choose tools that play nice together (integration matters)
 Invest in an ATS that’s user-friendly for recruiters and candidates
 Use a CRM to build and maintain talent pipelines
 Use platforms that have actionable hiring data
 Balance automation with a human touch

Your tech stack should simplify the process. Not complicate it.

Start small, scale smart.

The right tools aren’t just an expense—they’re an investment.

What tools have delivered the best ROI for your hiring process? Drop them below.

comments.commentText:
The right tech stack can make or break budgets and efficiency. 

Tools that don’t integrate? Money wasted. 

Clunky ATS systems? Time delays that drive up costs. 

Skipping CRM tools? No talent pipeline, so you’re stuck with urgent (and expensive) hires.

Ignoring metrics? Missed ROI opportunities.

Forgetting the candidate experience? Higher attrition and more rehiring headaches.

It all adds up fast.

Here are my top 4 tools to keep in your tech stack:
candidate.fyi - Probably the most powerful tool out there to create a quality candidate experience and uncover any bottlenecks in the interview process
Ashby - All in one Recruiting Platform that has an ATS, CRM & Email Outreach
Gem - CRM that gives you visibility into your funnel and your recruiting ROI
- End to end ATS & CRM for Recruiting & Staffing Agencies like
Anthony Escamilla

posts.name:
Keith Tode, MBA
Keith Tode, MBA
posts.content:
CAREER COACHING & PRICING: BUYER BEWARE!

You charge how much?!

$3999 a month is obscene.

If you can't afford to pay in cash, the company offers the opportunity to FINANCE their services at 0%.

How generous.

As if losing your job isn't traumatic enough, you now need to fend off the wolves in sheep's clothing who are preying on the fears and desperation of jobseekers.

Perhaps these predatory fees would be justified if Andrew Carnegie or JP Morgan was your personal coach, but since they aren't, it feels more like shakedown from the Gambino Crime Family.

The reality is that the CEO has a few years of recruiting experience and staffs his company with college interns whose only previous professional experience was bartending at the local wing joint.

So, definitely worth the price of a Caribbean vacation.

Enough is enough. There are a million and two free resources to help jobseekers with CV templates, cover letters, LinkedIn optimization and mock interview questions which don't require require selling a kidney or draining your bank account.

So, ask yourself if these coaches are really selling anything more than hope to drowning jobseekers who are looking for a professional life raft?

If all the the advice given (and sold) is so effective, why are there millions of people still looking for work?

Are they working for your best interests or their own?

Hint: you can have a perfectly written CV, a cover letter written by Shakespeare himself, a PhD and a Nobel Peace Price and still not get called to interview or receive an offer when there are simply more candidates than available jobs.

Fact.

Buyer beware, indeed.

BELIEVE IN YOURSELF AS MUCH AS I BELIEVE IN YOU!

comments.commentText:
Noticed post. In most cases with a basic education, you should be able to come up with a pretty decent cover letter, resume, and LI profile.
FYI free tips on LI and youtube "LinkedIn Optimization"

Just some of my "in the trenches" posts. No advertisement, sales, coaching, affiliations, referrals, or self promotion. Just FREE.
